section.title: Overview
section.para: All SQL statements are executed in sessions.

section.title: Statements
section.simpara: Start an SQL-transaction and set its characteristics. All transactional SQL statements start a transaction automatically, therefore using this statement is not necessary. If the statement is called in the middle of a transaction, an exception is thrown.

simpara.literal: <set transaction statement> ::= SET [ LOCAL ] TRANSACTION <transaction characteristics>

section.simpara: Set the characteristics of the next transaction for the agent. This statement has an effect only on the next transactions and has no effect on the future transactions after the next.

simpara.literal: <transaction access mode> ::= READ ONLY | READ WRITE
<level of isolation> ::= READ UNCOMMITTED | READ COMMITTED | REPEATABLE READ | SERIALIZABLE

<set constraints mode statement> ::= SET
    CONSTRAINTS <constraint name list> { DEFERRED | IMMEDIATE
    }

section.simpara: If an SQL-transaction is currently active, then set the constraint mode for that SQL-transaction in the current SQL-session. If no SQL-transaction is currently active, then set the constraint mode for the next SQL-transaction in the current SQL-session for the SQL-agent. NOTE 434 This statement has no effect on any SQL-transactions subsequent to this SQL-transaction.

simpara.literal: <commit statement> ::= COMMIT [ WORK ] [ AND [ NO ] CHAIN ]

section.simpara: Terminate the current SQL-transaction with commit.

simpara.literal: <rollback statement> ::= ROLLBACK [ WORK ] [ AND [ NO ] CHAIN ] [ <savepoint clause> ]

section.simpara: Terminate the current SQL-transaction with rollback, or rollback all actions affecting SQL-data since the establishment of a savepoint.
Terminate the current SQL session. Closing a JDBC connection has the same effect as this command.

simpara.literal: <set session characteristics statement> ::= SET SESSION CHARACTERISTICS AS <session characteristic list>

section.simpara: Set one or more characteristics for the current SQL-session. This command is used to set the transaction mode for the session. This endures until the next use of this command.

simpara.literal: <set session user identifier statement> ::= SET SESSION AUTHORIZATION <value specification>

section.simpara: Set the SQL-session user identifier. This statement changes the current user. The user that executes this command must have the CHANGE_AUTHORIZATION role, or the DBA role. After this statement is executed, all SQL statements are executed with the privileges of the new user.

Set the SQL-session role name and the current role name for the current SQL-session context. The user that executes this command must have the specifid role. If NONE is specified, then the previous CURRENT_ROLE is elminated. The effect of this lasts for the lifetime of the session.

simpara.literal: <set local time zone statement> ::= SET TIME ZONE <set time zone value>
<set time zone value> ::= <interval value expression> | LOCAL

section.simpara: Set the current default time zone displacement for the current SQL-session. When the session starts, the time zone displacement is set to the time zone of the client. This command changes the time zone displacement. The effect of this lasts for the lifetime of the session.

Set the default schema name for unqualified names used in SQL statements that are prepared or executed directly in the current sessions. As there is only one catalog in the database, only the name of this catalog can be used.

Set the default schema name for unqualified names used in SQL statements that are prepared or executed directly in the current sessions. The effect of this lasts for the lifetime of the session. The SQL Standard form requires the schema name as a single-quoted string. HyperSQL also allows the use of the identifier for the schema.

simpara.literal: <set names statement> ::= SET <character set name characteristic>

section.simpara: Set the default character set name for character string literals in preparable statements that are prepared in the current SQL-session by an execute immediate statement or a prepare statement and in direct SQL statements that are invoked directly.

Set the SQL-path used to determine the subject routine of routine invocations with unqualified routine names used in SQL statements that are prepared or executed directly in the current sessions. The effect of this lasts for the lifetime of the session.

simpara.literal: <set transform group statement> ::= SET <transform group characteristic>
<transform group characteristic> ::= DEFAULT TRANSFORM GROUP <value specification> | TRANSFORM GROUP FOR TYPE <path-resolved user-defined type name> <value specification>

section.simpara: Set the group name that identifies the group of transform functions for mapping values of user-defined types to predefined data types.

simpara.literal: <set session collation statement> ::= SET COLLATION <collation specification> [ FOR <character set specification list> ] | SET NO COLLATION [ FOR <character set specification list> ]

section.simpara: Set the SQL-session collation of the SQL-session for one or more character sets. The effect of this lasts for the lifetime of the session.
